title: Monostatic polytope
summary: In geometry, a monostatic polytope (or unistable polyhedron) is a d-polytope which "can stand on only one face". They were described in 1969 by J. H. Conway, M. Goldberg, R. K. Guy and K. C. Knowlton. The monostatic polytope in 3-space constructed independently by Guy and Knowlton has 19 faces. In 2012, Andras Bezdek discovered an 18-face solution,[1] and in 2014, Alex Reshetov published a 14-face object.[2]
